questions.text: A 12 y/o girl presents with headaches, vomiting, and altered mental status. MRI shows obstructive hydrocephalus caused by multiple cysts blocking cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Neurocysticercosis

Clinical Features

Stages of lesion
  • Seizures: The most common symptom, typically new-onset partial seizures that may generalize.
  • Headaches
  • Hydrocephalus: Caused by cysts obstructing cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow, leading to increased pressure.
  • Cognitive and Personality Changes
  • Focal Neurological Deficits (weakness or sensory disturbances)
  • Increased Intracranial Pressure (nausea, vomiting, ataxia, visual deficits, papilledema)
  • Vesicular: Cystic lesions with scolex. The parasite is viable. (Live stage)
  • Colloidal: Cysts degenerate, causing surrounding oedema. (Degenerating stage)
  • Granulonodular: Cysts with less oedema, more solidified. (Degenerating stage)
  • Nodular-Calcified: Parasite is no longer viable. Cysts calcify, with no active inflammation. (Dead stage)

questions.text: A 45 y/o man presents with fever, a headache, and focal neurological deficits on the right side. He had dental surgery two weeks ago. CT shows a ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding oedema in the left temporal lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Brain Tumor and Brain Abscess
 

Brain Tumour

Brain Abscess

Cause

Abnormal growth of cells in the brain or meninges.

Localised collection of pus due to infection.

Symptoms

Headaches, nausea, and vomiting due to raised intracranial pressure.

Seizures and gradual neurological deficits.

Headaches, fever (in about half of cases), focal deficits, and sometimes seizures.

Diagnosis

MRI and CT scan

Biopsy confirms the type and grade

MRI is preferred, CT-guided aspiration identifies the infectious agent.

Treatment

Surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy.

High-dose intravenous antibiotics and surgical drainage.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common brain tumour in childhood?

Match the following syndromes with their most commonly seen brain tumours respectively. 1. Von Hippel Landau a) Bilateral vestibular schwannomas 2. Tuberous sclerosis b) Glioma 3. Neurofibromatosis 2 c) Hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum 4. Li Fraumeni Syndrome d) Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
questions.explanation:
Syndrome

Associated Tumours

Cowden's syndrome

Dysplastic cerebellar gangliocytoma (Lhermitte-Duclos disease), meningioma, astrocytoma, breast, endometrial, thyroid cancer, trichilemmomas

Gardner's syndrome

Medulloblastoma, glioblastoma, craniopharyngioma, familial polyposis, multiple osteomas, skin and soft tissue tumours

Li-Fraumeni syndrome

Gliomas, medulloblastomas, sarcomas, breast cancer, leukaemia, and others

Lynch syndrome

Glioblastomas and other gliomas

Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (Wermer's syndrome)

Pituitary adenoma, malignant schwannoma and pancreatic islet cell tumours

NF1

Schwannomas, astrocytomas, optic nerve gliomas, meningiomas, neurofibromas, neurofibrosarcomas, and others

NF2

Bilateral vestibular schwannomas, astrocytomas, multiple meningiomas, ependymomas

Tuberous Sclerosis (Bourneville disease)

Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ependymomas, glioma, ganglioneuroma, hamartoma

Turcot syndrome

Gliomas, medulloblastomas

Von Hippel Landau

Hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum, retinal angiomas, renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, pancreatic tumours and cysts, endolymphatic sac tumours of the middle ear

questions.text: A 40 y/o man with a known brain tumour has recently undergone radiation therapy. During a follow-up visit, his doctor ordered imaging studies to evaluate the tumour. The physician wants to determine whether the changes observed on the imaging are due to tumour progression or necrosis resulting from treatment. Which imaging technique can help differentiate between the two?

A 22 y/o man is suspected to have a brain tumour after presenting with several concerning symptoms. He also reports episodes of nausea and difficulty with balance. Which of the following features when present will you not suspect brain tumors?
questions.correct_answer: D. Decreased skin sensitivity to temperature

questions.text: Identify the correct statements on CNS tumours. Calcifications are found in Meningioma and Oligodendroglioma. Rathke’s cyst and Craniopharyngioma are present as suprasellar masses. Meningioma and Glioblastoma multiforme never cross the midline. Giant cell Astrocytoma and Ependymoma occur as Intraventricular tumours. Schwannoma is an important Cerebello-pontine angle tumour. Metastatic lesions are never present in the suprasellar area.
questions.explanation:
Important Facts on CNS Tumours

Sellar/ Suprasellar Tumours

(Statement 2 & Statement 6)

Cerebello-Pontine Angle Tumors

(Statement 5)
  • Pituitary Adenoma
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Rathke’s cyst
  • Meningioma (Presence of Dural tail)
  • Schwannoma
  • Dermoid
  • Germinoma
  • Metastasis
  • Schwannoma
  • Meningioma
  • Epidermoid
  • Arachnoid cyst
  • Paraganglioma
  • Metastasis

Calcifications in CNS Tumours

(Statement 1)

Midline Crossing CNS Tumours

(Statement 3)
  • Meningioma
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Oligodendroglioma
  • Chordoma
  • Ependymoma
  • Metastasis
  • Glioblastoma multiforme
  • Radiation necrosis
  • Meningioma
  • Lymphoma
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Multiple Sclerosis

Tumour mimics

Intraventricular Tumours

(Statement 4)
  • Abscess
  • Multiple sclerosis (Tumefactive)
  • Aneurysm
  • Infections- Eg. Herpes encephalitis, tuberculoma, neurocysticercosis
  • Dural AV Fistula
  • Ependymoma
  • Subependymoma
  • Meningioma
  • Choroid Plexus Papilloma
  • Giant cell Astrocytoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common primary malignant brain tumour in adults?

A 32 y/o female presents to the ED with seizures and headaches. An MRI Contrast of the brain is given below. The neurologist is considering treatment options based on the imaging findings. Given the presence of multiple viable cystic lesions on the CT scan, which of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate?

A 30 y/o male presents to the clinic with progressive headaches, fever, and weight loss over the past month. Neurological examination reveals focal deficits and a CT scan of the brain is given below. The patient also exhibits signs of meningitis. Based on the clinical presentation and CT findings, which of the following conditions is most likely diagnosed?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Neurocysticercosis

Tuberculoma of the Brain

Lesions

Smaller (< 20 mm), single or multiple

(Option A ruled out)

Larger (> 20 mm), often multiple, conglomerated.

Associated Meningitis

Absent

Present

Location

Junction of grey-white matter

Common in the posterior fossa

MR Spectroscopy

Multiple amino acid peaks

Lipid peaks

Focal Neurological Deficits

Absent

Present

Raised ICP

Transient

Present

Constitutional Symptoms

Absent

Present

CT images

questions.text: A 28 y/o female presents to the neurology clinic with recurrent headaches and occasional seizures. An MRI of the brain is performed to evaluate her symptoms. The gadolinium-enhanced MRI shows cystic lesions as shown in the image below. Based on the MRI findings described, which stage of the clinical condition does this lesion represent?

A 35 y/o male presents with new-onset seizures and persistent headaches. He gives a history of travel to China a month ago. A CT scan of the brain is performed, revealing several ill-defined lesions with surrounding oedema and ring enhancement. Based on these imaging findings, which of the following is the confirmatory test for the condition?

A 52 y/o man with a history of hypertension suddenly collapses. Imaging confirms a large left-sided brain infarction. His ICP is elevated, and the neurosurgical team is concerned about herniation. What type of herniation is most commonly associated with increased ICP?

A 32 y/o man from a rural area presents with recurrent seizures. He recalls occasionally eating undercooked pork and living in a community with poor sanitation. A brain MRI shows multiple cystic lesions. What is the most likely cause of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Infection by adult Taenia solium tapeworms in the intestines

options.label: B
options.text: Ingestion of T. solium eggs from contaminated food or hands

options.label: C
options.text: Eating undercooked pork containing adult tapeworms

options.label: D
options.text: Migration of larvae from the lungs to the brain

questions.correct_answer: B. Ingestion of T. solium eggs from contaminated food or hands

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is known to mimic coma but does not involve actual loss of consciousness?
questions.explanation:
Reversible Coma

Causes of Reversible Coma

Treatment of Reversible Coma 

Metabolic Coma:

  • Results from lack of oxygen/glucose or disrupted neuronal excitability.
  • Conditions include hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hypercalcemia, and hepatic/renal failure. (Option C ruled out)
  • Hepatic encephalopathy and uremic encephalopathy cause coma due to elevated ammonia levels and elevated creatinine/ guanidine respectively. (Option A and B ruled out)

Drug/Toxin-Induced Coma:

  • It is caused by drugs or toxins that affect the brainstem's reticular activating system (RAS) and cerebral cortex.
  • Some drugs, like barbiturates, may mimic brain death signs.

Epileptic Coma:

  • Generalised seizures (nonconvulsive status epilepticus) can cause coma.
  • EEG is essential for detecting treatable seizures in unexplained coma.

Immediate Interventions:

  • Prevent further brain damage.
  • Correct hypotension, hypoglycemia, hypercalcemia, hypoxia, hypercapnia.

Airway Management:

  • Oropharyngeal airway for drowsy patients with normal breathing.
  • Tracheal intubation for apnea, obstruction, or aspiration risk.

Medications:

  • Naloxone for opioid overdose.
  • Dextrose for hypoglycemia.
  • Thiamine for malnourished patients (prevent Wernicke’s encephalopathy).
  • Physostigmine for anticholinergic overdose (with caution).
  • Fomepizole for ethylene glycol poisoning.

Additional Considerations:

  • Manage strokes with tPA or embolectomy after ruling out haemorrhage.
  • Avoid hypotonic IV fluids in brain illness to prevent swelling.
  • Treat bacterial meningitis promptly with antibiotics and dexamethasone.

questions.text: A 50 y/o woman presents with persistent headaches, double vision, and vomiting and also experiences worsening morning headaches. Examination shows reactive pupils and limited right eye lateral movement. Which cranial nerve is most likely affected by increased intracranial pressure?
A 35 y/o male is declared brain dead after a severe head injury. His family consents to organ donation. Which of the following organs is most commonly transplanted from a brain-dead donor?
questions.explanation:
Organ Transplantation from the Brain-Dead

Organ donation occurs after confirming brain death. Two doctors with specific qualifications must confirm brain death through tests separately. Although brain dead, the patient remains ventilated to keep organs viable for transplantation.

Organ Transplantation

Indication

Kidney Transplantation (Option D)

Most common transplantation. Performed for end-stage renal disease (ESRD). Common causes are Diabetic nephropathy, hypertension, and glomerulonephritis.

Liver Transplantation (Option C ruled out)

Second most common transplantation. Done for Cirrhosis, liver cancers, acute hepatic failure and cholestatic diseases.

Heart Transplantation (Option B ruled out)

Refractory heart failure due to cardiomyopathy, coronary artery disease, and congenital defects.

Lung Transplantation

Performed for severe respiratory failure, e.g., idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, emphysema, cystic fibrosis.

Pancreas Transplantation (Option A ruled out)

Often combined with kidney transplantation in diabetic patients with ESRD to reverse diabetes and its complications.

questions.text: A 38 y/o man with severe brain injury is undergoing tests to confirm brain death. The apnoea test is part of the evaluation. What is the purpose of the apnoea test in brain death diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: To evaluate cardiac function during hypoxia

options.label: C
options.text: To measure oxygenation levels during ventilation

questions.correct_answer: A. To assess spontaneous respiratory effort
questions.explanation:
Brain Death Investigations

Brain death refers to the permanent cessation of all brain and brainstem functions while cardiac activity and other bodily functions are maintained artificially. It is legally and ethically equivalent to death.

Preconditions for Brain Death Testing
  • Deep coma with no influence of depressant drugs.
  • No hypothermia (body temperature >35°C).
  • Normal electrolyte, acid-base, and glucose levels, no metabolic or endocrine causes.
  • No spontaneous respiration due to ventilatory dependence.
  • The underlying condition causing brain damage must be irremediable.

Clinical Tests to Confirm Brain Death

Absence of brainstem reflexes:

  • Fixed, non-reactive pupils.
  • Absent corneal and vestibulo-ocular reflexes.
  • No motor response to cranial nerve stimulation.
  • Absent gag reflex and no response to tracheal suctioning.

Apnoea Test:

  • Checks for Spontaneous respiratory effort. (Option A)
  • There is no respiratory effort in brain death when disconnected from the ventilator, despite PaCO2 rising above 50 mmHg.

Additional Investigations

A four-vessel angiogram or isotope brain scan is used to confirm the absence of cerebral blood flow, particularly in complex cases.

Testing Protocol: Must be performed by two experienced doctors and repeated after a short interval to confirm the diagnosis. Once brain death is confirmed, organ donation may be considered with appropriate consent.

questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents to the ED after experiencing a severe headache, nausea, and confusion for the past few hours. O/E, the physician observes a slow heart rate, high blood pressure, and irregular respiratory patterns. What other clinical finding is most likely to be observed in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased pupil size on the affected side

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased pupil size on the affected side

questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents to the emergency department after a cardiac arrest. He was resuscitated and remains comatose. A CT scan reveals cerebral oedema and midline shift, indicating raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Which Tier 2 therapy would be most appropriate for managing his elevated ICP?
questions.explanation:
Tier 2 Therapy

Tier 2 therapy refers to advanced interventions for managing persistent elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) when initial treatments (Tier 1) are ineffective. Both therapeutic hypothermia and decompressive hemicraniectomy aim to minimise brain damage and enhance patient outcomes.

Therapeutic Hypothermia (32-36°C)

(Option A)
  • Indication: Primarily for hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) following cardiac arrest.
  • Mechanism: Slows neuronal injury processes by lowering body temperature, potentially reducing brain damage.
  • Clinical Evidence: Proven effective in improving outcomes for comatose patients after resuscitation, with trials showing benefits at mild hypothermia (33°C).
  • Guidelines: Recommended for 24 hours in unresponsive cardiac arrest patients, target temperature is typically 32-36°C.

Decompressive Hemicraniectomy

(Option B ruled out)
  • Indication: For refractory elevated ICP that persists despite other treatments.
  • Procedure: Involves surgically removing a portion of the skull to relieve pressure on the swollen brain.
  • Clinical Evidence: Shown to improve outcomes in select patients, especially in cases of severe traumatic brain injury and significant brain swelling.

Pentobarbital Coma
  • Indication: Considered for refractory ICP
  • Application: It is not as commonly used as other therapies but may be applied in specific circumstances.

questions.text: A patient in the ICU exhibits signs of severe brain dysfunction and demonstrates decerebrate posturing. What should the healthcare team consider regarding intracranial pressure (ICP) management?

options.label: A
options.text: ICP monitoring is unnecessary and they should focus on other interventions

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate intervention is required for elevated ICP

options.label: C
options.text: The prognosis is good despite posturing

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid ventriculostomy as it may worsen the condition

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediate intervention is required for elevated ICP
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Real-Time Monitoring : Facilitates immediate assessment of ICP, guiding treatment decisions.
  • ↳ Pressure Relief : Reduces ICP through CSF drainage, potentially improving patient outcomes.
  • ↳ Guides Treatment : Informs other therapies, such as osmotic therapy or sedation.
  • ↳ Preference : Generally favoured over parenchymal ICP monitoring when CSF drainage is necessary.

questions.text: A patient with fulminant hepatic failure is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). The patient is at risk of increased intracranial pressure due to cerebral oedema. What is the primary goal of management of ICP in this patient?
questions.explanation:
ICP Monitoring

Critical for managing patients with severe brain injury. Real-time ICP measurements enable timely interventions and treatment adjustments to prevent further brain injury.

Indications for ICP Monitoring:
  • Severe Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI): Especially when the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 8 or lower.
  • Major Brain Tissue Displacement
    • Large Ischemic or Hemorrhagic Strokes
    • Hydrocephalus
  • Fulminant Hepatic Failure

Methods of ICP Monitoring
  • Ventriculostomy: Involves inserting a catheter into the brain’s lateral ventricles. Allows for direct measurement of ICP and therapeutic drainage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to lower pressure.
  • Parenchymal Monitoring: Involves placing a sensor directly into brain tissue. Used when ventriculostomy is not suitable due to diffuse oedema or coagulopathy.

Goals of ICP Management

  • Maintain ICP below 20 mmHg: To prevent brain ischemia and herniation. (Option A) (Option B ruled out)
  • Maintain Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP) above 60 mmHg: Ensures adequate blood flow to the brain despite elevated ICP. (Option C ruled out)
    • Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP) is the pressure gradient that drives blood flow to the brain. Adequate CPP is essential for delivering oxygen and nutrients to neuronal tissues while removing metabolic waste products.
    • It is calculated using the formula: CPP = Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) - Intracranial Pressure (ICP).

questions.text: A 35 y/o male is brought to the ED after a road traffic accident. He is unconscious with a GCS score of 6. His blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and he exhibits symptoms of bradycardia and irregular respiration. What is the first step in managing his raised intracranial pressure?
questions.explanation:
Raised Intracranial Pressure (ICP)

Causes

Trauma, tumours, haemorrhage, or hydrocephalus can lead to increased ICP.

Symptoms

Headache, vomiting, altered consciousness, papilledema (swelling of the optic disc), unequal pupils due to brainstem compression

Cushing's triad: Hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration

Management of Raised ICP (when ICP>20-25mmHg for >5min)

Initial Measures

(Option C)
  • Head elevation: Raising the head to 30 degrees enhances venous drainage and reduces ICP by promoting blood flow out of the brain.
  • Sedation: Sedating the patient with agents like midazolam reduces metabolic demands on the brain, helping control ICP.

Medical Therapies

Osmotherapy (Mannitol or Hypertonic saline): (Option B ruled out)

  • Mannitol acts as an osmotic diuretic, reducing cerebral oedema by drawing fluid from brain tissue.
  • Hypertonic saline works similarly by pulling water from brain cells into the bloodstream, lowering brain swelling.
  • Contraindication: Active intracranial bleeding

Glucocorticoids: Effective in reducing vasogenic oedema, particularly in cases involving tumours, but not used for trauma-induced ICP.

Ventilation Strategies

Hyperventilation: Temporarily reduces ICP by inducing cerebral vasoconstriction, leading to decreased blood flow. This is a short-term measure that requires careful monitoring to avoid ischemia. (Option A ruled out)

CSF Drainage

In cases of hydrocephalus or ventricular enlargement, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) can be drained through a catheter to relieve pressure.

Ventriculostomy is the procedure.

Pressor therapy

Common pressors like phenylephrine, dopamine, and norepinephrine raise MAP to ensure cerebral blood flow and relieve ischemia by promoting autoregulatory vasoconstriction and reducing intracranial blood volume. Pressor therapy is used only after other treatments fail.

Advanced Therapies

Decompressive craniectomy: A surgical procedure where part of the skull is removed to allow the brain to swell without causing further pressure buildup. This is considered when ICP remains uncontrolled by other measures.
